name: SUID Binary Privilege Escalation (Basic)
description: Exploit misconfigured SUID binary using GTFOBins to gain root shell
prerequisites: Shell access as low-privilege user (www-data, user, etc.)
notes: SUID binaries with setuid bit set run with owner's privileges (usually root). Misconfigured binaries like find, vim, nmap, base64 can be exploited for privilege escalation. GTFOBins provides exploitation techniques. This chain covers the most common OSCP scenario: finding SUID binary and exploiting it for root shell.

steps.name: Enumerate SUID Binaries
steps.objective: Locate all SUID binaries on system using find command
steps.description: Search entire filesystem for files with SUID bit set (-perm -4000). Redirect errors to /dev/null to avoid permission denied noise.
evidence: Custom or unusual SUID binaries visible
success_criteria: Results include non-standard binaries (not just passwd, sudo, ping)
failure_conditions: All directories permission denied (wrong user context)
No results returned (unlikely on real system)

steps.name: Identify Exploitable SUID Binaries
steps.objective: Filter out standard system binaries and focus on exploitable candidates
steps.description: Exclude common system binaries (passwd, sudo, ping, mount) that are expected to have SUID. Look for: find, vim, nmap, base64, less, more, python, perl, awk, etc.
success_criteria: At least one binary has known GTFOBins technique
Binaries are executable by current user
failure_conditions: No interesting binaries remain after filtering
All binaries are standard system tools
Binaries require specific conditions not present

steps.name: Lookup GTFOBins Exploitation Technique
steps.objective: Find exploitation technique for discovered SUID binary on GTFOBins website
steps.description: Visit https://gtfobins.github.io/ and search for binary name. Look for 'SUID' section specifically. Copy exploitation command syntax.
success_criteria: Command syntax is clear and testable

steps.name: Execute SUID Exploitation
steps.objective: Run GTFOBins command to escalate privileges and spawn root shell
steps.description: Execute exploitation command exactly as documented on GTFOBins. Common example: /usr/bin/find . -exec /bin/bash -p \; -quit
evidence: Shell prompt changes to root indicator
failure_conditions: Shell spawns but not privileged (missing -p flag for bash)

steps.name: Verify Root Access
steps.objective: Confirm effective UID is 0 and full root privileges obtained
steps.description: Run whoami and id commands to verify root access. Check if you can read /etc/shadow or /root/ directory.
evidence: id output: uid=0(root) gid=0(root) or euid=0(root)
failure_conditions: Effective UID differs from real UID (may need -p flag)
